position.marginalia_text: egregij fatti, et aguti detti di Castruccio, cioè, di Aristippo, Diogene, Bione: onde appare l'arguto, e faceto humore del Macchiauelli. Vita del Esopo.

marginalia.translation: The illustrious facts and clever sayings of Castruccio, that is, of Aristippus, Diogenes of Sinope, Bion of Smyrna: from whom comes the clever and witty humor of Machiavelli. The life of Aesop.

position.marginalia_text: Apophthegmata Hebra[e]oru[m], et Arabum: à Drusio nouissimè collecta. scita, et salsa.

marginalia.translation: Jewish and Arabic aphorisms, collected most recently by Drusius. Clever and witty.

position.marginalia_text: { Maior Natura[e], et Exercitationis valor, quàm Artis.

marginalia.translation: There is no greater valor of nature and exercise than that of art.

position.marginalia_text: { Sapiens est, qui multa nouit Natura[e] solertiâ: qui autem disciplina vsi fuerunt, uehementes garrulitate velùt Corui, irrita clamant Jouis aduersùs auem diuinam. Pindarus Ode 2. Olympiorum.

marginalia.translation:
"The man who knows a great deal by nature is truly skillful, while those who have only learned chatter with raucous and indiscriminate tongues in vain like crows against the divine bird of Zeus." Pindar's second Olympian Ode.
[Translation from Perseus Project; Diane Arnson Svarlien]

position.marginalia_text: Telamoni nunq[uam] timor viroru[m] domitor extinxit fortitudinem animi. Sic ex ingenita virtute illustri quisq[ue] magnum pondus obtinet + At/qui ex disciplina accepit ea qua[e] habet obscurus vir, aliàs alia spirans, nunq[uam] pede exactè stabili incedit, sed infinitas Virtutes insufficienti mente degustat. Idem Idem 3. Nemeorum. { Horatio Dirca[e]us Cygnus.

marginalia.translation:
"And fear, the subduer of men, never dulled the edge of Telamon's mind. A man with inborn glory has great weight; but he who has only learned is a man in darkness, breathing changeful purposes, never taking an unwavering step, but trying his hand at countless forms of excellence with his ineffectual thought." Pindar's third Nemean Ode (in Horace, he is the Thebean swan).
[Translation from Perseus Project; Diane Arnson Svarlien]

position.marginalia_text: Hieron, decerpens summitates ex singulis virtutibus.

marginalia.translation: "Hieron, reaping every excellence at its peak." "Reaping every excellence at its peak." Pindar's first Olympian Ode. [Translation from Perseus Project; Diane Arnson Svarlien]

position.marginalia_text: Omnis Natura pra[e]clarior fit, si conformatio qua[e]dam doctrina[e] accesserit: longè verò maximè ijs, quibus contigit meliorem ab initio sortiri, quàm alijs. Illis enim sese tantùm vincere: his verò alijs etiam pra[e]stare accidit. Demosthenes in Erotica.

marginalia.translation:
"All natural ability is improved by the addition of the appropriate education, and this is especially true of talents which at the outset are inherently superior to the rest, because the one kind is capable only of improving upon itself while the other may also surpass the rest." The Erotic Essay of Demosthenes.
[Translation from Perseus Project; Norman Wentworth DeWitt]

position.marginalia_text: Posteri dies, testes sunt sapientissimi. Pind. Ode. I.

marginalia.translation:
"The days to come are the wisest witnesses." Pindar's first Olympian Ode.
[Translation from Perseus Project; Diane Arnson Svarlien]

position.marginalia_text: Certè magis est radicale, quod Natura, et Exercitatione infigitur, quàm quod Arte inseritur.

marginalia.translation: Certainly it is more radical that nature is fixed by practice, rather than grafted on by art.

position.marginalia_text: Nulla vtilitas est vel vtilissima[e] Artis, sine assidua Exercitatione. R. in Corollario Scholarum Dialecticaru[m].

book.title: Scholarum dialectarum seu animadversionum in Organum Aristotelis

marginalia.translation: Even the most useful art is useless without constant practice. R. in the deduction from his Scholarum Dialecticarum.
